nodes.label: Case

source.description: The origin of the data (e.g., 'Official Court Website', 'LexisNexis', 'Manual Entry').

extracted_at.description: Timestamp of when the data was extracted from the source.

extracted_by.description: Identifier for the process or user that extracted the data (e.g., 'Scraper v2.1', 'user:jane.doe').

confidence_score.description: A score from 0.0 to 1.0 indicating the confidence in the accuracy of the extracted data.

version.description: An integer that increments with each update to the node, for tracking changes over time.

changelog.description: A log of changes made in each version, typically stored as a JSON string.

trust_score.description: A composite score reflecting the overall trustworthiness of the node, calculated from authority, verification, and citations.

authority_level.description: The legal authority of the document (e.g., a Supreme Court decision is 'Binding').

citation_count.description: The number of other documents in the graph that cite this document.

verification_status.description: The status of human or automated verification of the node's content.

nodes.description: Represents a single legal case or judgment. It is the central node for case law analysis, linking to parties, judges, courts, statutes, and other cases.

nodes.label: Statute

created_at.description: Timestamp of when the node was first created in the database.

updated_at.description: Timestamp of the last update to the node.

source.description: The origin of the data (e.g., 'Official Gazette', 'Government Portal').

extracted_at.description: Timestamp of when the data was extracted from the source.

extracted_by.description: Identifier for the process or user that extracted the data.

confidence_score.description: A score from 0.0 to 1.0 indicating the confidence in the accuracy of the extracted text.

version.description: An integer that increments with each amendment or update to the statute.

changelog.description: A log of amendments or changes made in each version.

trust_score.description: A composite score reflecting the overall trustworthiness of the statute text.

authority_level.description: The legal authority of the statute.

citation_count.description: The number of cases or other documents that cite this statute.

verification_status.description: The status of verification against the official source.

nodes.description: Represents a legislative act, ordinance, or code, such as the Code of Civil Procedure. It serves as a container for its structural components like Parts, Orders, and Sections.

nodes.label: Section
nodes.description: A specific section of a Statute. This is a primary unit of statutory law that cases interpret and apply.

nodes.label: Judge
nodes.description: Represents a judge who presides over cases. Linking cases to judges allows for analysis of judicial tendencies and influence.

nodes.label: Court

properties.name: string (e.g., 'Appellate Division, Supreme Court of Bangladesh')

nodes.description: Represents a court or tribunal where a case is heard. Essential for understanding the procedural hierarchy and venue.

nodes.label: Party
nodes.description: A litigant (person or entity) involved in a case, such as a petitioner or respondent.

nodes.label: Principle
nodes.description: A specific legal principle or ratio decidendi established or affirmed in a case. This node abstracts the core legal reasoning for analytical purposes.

nodes.label: Doctrine
nodes.description: A well-established legal doctrine that may be applied across multiple cases. Unlike a Principle, a Doctrine is a broader, named concept.

nodes.label: Holding
nodes.description: The specific ruling or decision on a point of law in a case. It is the direct answer to a legal question posed in the case.

nodes.label: Appeal
nodes.description: Represents the procedural event of an appeal, linking the lower court case to the appellate court case and capturing metadata about the appeal itself.

nodes.label: Motion
nodes.description: A procedural request made by a party during a case for the court to take a specific action.

nodes.label: Part
nodes.description: A structural division of a Statute, like the Parts in the Code of Civil Procedure. It contains Sections.

nodes.label: Order
nodes.description: A structural division of a procedural code like the CPC. It contains Rules.

nodes.label: Definition
nodes.description: A formal definition of a term provided within a Statute, typically in a definitions section.

nodes.label: Rule
nodes.description: A specific rule within an Order of a procedural code like the CPC. It provides detailed procedural instructions.

nodes.label: CaseVersion
nodes.description: Represents a specific published version of a case in a law reporter. This allows for multiple citations to point to a single canonical Case node.

nodes.label: Amendment
nodes.description: Represents a specific legislative amendment event that changes a Statute or its components.

nodes.label: ChangeLog
nodes.description: A generic node to track changes or versions of any legal entity, particularly for tracking the evolution of statutory text over time.

nodes.label: Chunk
nodes.description: A text segment from a larger document (Case or Section), optimized for semantic search. Each chunk has a vector embedding for similarity search. Properties like offsets and sequence ID allow for precise source attribution and context assembly. Runtime metadata such as 'relevance_score' and 'rerank_score' will be associated with this node during a query.

nodes.label: Case

source.description: The origin of the data (e.g., 'Official Court Website', 'LexisNexis', 'Manual Entry').

extracted_at.description: Timestamp of when the data was extracted from the source.

extracted_by.description: Identifier for the process or user that extracted the data (e.g., 'Scraper v2.1', 'user:jane.doe').

confidence_score.description: A score from 0.0 to 1.0 indicating the confidence in the accuracy of the extracted data.

version.description: An integer that increments with each update to the node, for tracking changes over time.

changelog.description: A log of changes made in each version, typically stored as a JSON string.

trust_score.description: A composite score reflecting the overall trustworthiness of the node, calculated from authority, verification, and citations.

authority_level.description: The legal authority of the document (e.g., a Supreme Court decision is 'Binding').

citation_count.description: The number of other documents in the graph that cite this document.

verification_status.description: The status of human or automated verification of the node's content.

nodes.description: Represents a single legal case. The new 'embedding' property holds a vector representation of the case summary or another representative text, enabling case-level semantic search as part of a multi-granularity retrieval strategy.

nodes.label: Section
nodes.description: A specific section of a Statute. The new 'embedding' property contains a vector of the section's text, allowing for direct semantic retrieval of statutory provisions, complementing chunk-level search within cases.

properties.cited_for: string (e.g., 'On the principle of natural justice')

relationships.description: Connects a case to a precedent it cites. This is the fundamental relationship for building citation networks.
A strong negative citation where a higher court explicitly overrules the legal principle of a prior case.
Connects an appellate case to the lower court case it is upholding. Part of the procedural history.
Connects a case to a precedent it is differentiating itself from, explaining why the precedent does not apply.
A hierarchical relationship showing that one structural element is a component of another (e.g., a Section is PART_OF a Statute; a Rule is PART_OF an Order).
Synonymous with PART_OF, explicitly linking a statutory component to its parent Act.
Crucial relationship linking case law to statutory law, indicating that a case has applied or interpreted a specific section of a statute.
Connects a case to the judge(s) who heard and decided it.
Indicates which court heard and delivered the judgment for a case.
Identifies a party as the petitioner or plaintiff in a case.
Identifies a party as the respondent or defendant in a case.
Shows that an Amendment event has altered a Section or an entire Statute.
Indicates that a new statute has completely replaced an older one.
Links a specific published version (e.g., from DLR) to the abstract, canonical case entity.
Connects an appeal event to the original, lower court case.
Connects an appeal event to the new, appellate court case.
Indicates that a landmark case has established a new legal principle.
Connects a case to its specific legal holding(s).
Connects a motion to the case in which it was filed.
Connects a text Chunk to its parent document (a Case or a Section). This hierarchical link is essential for context assembly and providing accurate source attribution in RAG responses.

A granular citation link from a specific text Chunk to a Case it mentions. This allows retrieval to find the exact context where a precedent was discussed, far more precise than a document-level 'CITES_PRECEDENT' link.
Connects a Chunk from a case judgment to a statutory Section it refers to. This relationship is crucial for finding judicial interpretations of specific laws at the most granular level.

indexes.name: case_jurisdiction_date_type_idx
indexes.notes: Supports common filtering patterns for browsing cases by jurisdiction and time. Assumes 'case_type' property exists. Uses 'decisionDate' from schema for 'date' requirement.

indexes.name: case_jurisdiction_year_idx
indexes.notes: A more granular index for yearly reviews within a jurisdiction. Assumes 'year' property is added to the Case node for performance.

indexes.name: section_statute_part_number_idx
indexes.notes: Enables fast lookup of specific sections within a statute. Assumes 'statute_title' is denormalized onto the Section node.

indexes.name: case_embedding_index
indexes.notes: For case-level semantic search and retrieval.

indexes.name: section_embedding_index
indexes.notes: For finding relevant statutory provisions via semantic search.

indexes.name: chunk_embedding_index
indexes.notes: Primary index for granular semantic search across the entire text corpus.

indexes.name: case_fulltext_idx
indexes.notes: Supports keyword search across key textual fields of a Case.

indexes.name: section_fulltext_idx
indexes.notes: Supports keyword search on the title and text of statutory Sections.

indexes.name: case_citation_idx
indexes.notes: Critical for direct case lookup. Uniqueness constraint ensures data integrity.

indexes.name: section_id_idx
indexes.notes: For direct lookup of a specific section. Uniqueness constraint ensures a reliable internal identifier.

indexes.name: case_trust_score_idx
indexes.notes: For efficient filtering and sorting of cases based on their calculated trust or relevance score.

indexes.name: case_year_idx
indexes.notes: Optimizes queries that filter or range scan on the year of the case, a very common access pattern.

indexes.name: chunk_embedding_index
indexes.description: Primary index for semantic search. Enables finding the most relevant text snippets across the entire legal corpus in response to a user query.

indexes.name: case_embedding_index
indexes.description: Index for case-level retrieval. Used in a multi-granularity strategy to first identify relevant cases and then drill down to find relevant chunks within them.

indexes.name: section_embedding_index
indexes.description: Index for section-level retrieval. Allows users to find relevant statutory provisions directly via semantic search.

constraints.name: enforce_relationship_integrity
constraints.details: All relationships must connect to existing start and end nodes. Deleting a node must also delete its connecting relationships.

rag_configuration.retrieval_strategy: Hybrid (Vector + Graph) with Multi-Granularity Fallback. The primary path is vector search on the 'chunk_embedding_index'. Retrieved chunks are then expanded by traversing 'CHUNK_OF', 'CITES_IN_CHUNK', and 'REFERENCES' relationships to build context. If initial chunk search is insufficient, the system can fall back to a broader search on 'case_embedding_index' or 'section_embedding_index' to identify relevant documents before narrowing the search to chunks within those documents.
